body: Penelope Karagias, a Brooklyn real-estate broker who was active in apartment sales in Brooklyn Heights, Park Slope, Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens, was found dead of carbon-monoxide poisoning on Tuesday morning in a garage opposite one of her offices at 343 Smith Street, the police reported. Miss Karagias was 43 years old and lived at 221 Carroll
title: Penelope Karagias, a Broker Of Brooklyn Apartment Sales

body: The Boerum and Cobble Hill sections of Brooklyn are among the outer-borough neighborhoods that have become magnets for young professionals in search of affordable housing. The developers of a former commercial building on the corner of Smith and Wyckoff Streets, in an area wedged between the neighborhoods, have designed their new condominium
title: POSTINGS; Brooklyn Condos: 42 Affordables

body: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 36 food establishments cited for violating the health code. In addition, it listed five that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and two that were closed for having failed to do so. The establishments are these: Violations MANHATTAN Bar, 1053 St. Nicholas
title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 36 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES

body: The quaint, tree-lined streets of the Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens sections of Brooklyn were turned into a muddy construction zone yesterday as utility workers sought to restore gas service interrupted by a broken water main. Inside the homes along the avenues and streets, residents assessed their damage from flooding. Mario and Giovanna
title: AFTER WATER-MAIN BREAK IN BROOKLYN, RESIDENTS AND UTILITY START CLEANING UP

body: International A body washed up on Syria's coast is almost certainly that of Leon Klinghoffer of New York, the 69-year-old tourist reported slain by the hijackers of an Italian cruise liner, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said that there was a bullet hole in the skull of the partly decomposed body and that the shot seemed to have
title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1985

body: A water-main break caused damage that left almost 2,000 homes in Brooklyn without gas, water or phone service yesterday. By late afternoon, water and phone service had been restored to most of the homes - which are Carroll Gardens, Cobble Hill and part of Red Hook - but officials said it would be several days before gas was completely restored.
title: WATER AND GAS CUT OFF TO 2,000 IN BROOKLYN

body: Architects at Work, Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue (50th Street), 212-935-3960. The first of four tours of architectural firms will be presented by the society Tuesday from 1 to 2:30 P.M. The visits will show the departments of the firms and the phases of an architectural project. The other dates are Oct. 15, 22 and 29. Reservations
title: CALENDAR: TOUR OF ARCHITECTURAL FIRMS

body: The New York City Department of Health last week cited 19 food establishments for violating the health code. In addition, it listed four that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and nine that were closed for having failed to do so. The establishments are these: Violations MANHATTAN Larry's Natural Ice, 25 W. 39th St. Lasker
title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 19 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES

body: BROOKLYN is a borough of well-defined neighborhoods, and Court Street is a chain that ties several of them together. From Brooklyn Heights to Red Hook, the languages heard on Court Street, whether Arabic, Italian or the cadences of Wall Street, reflect the traditions of these neighborhoods. In much the same way, the food along the street, in both
title: ONE BROOKLYN STREET, MANY ETHNIC FLAVORS

body: To the Editor: Please accept this citizen's outrage at ''When the Trash Can't Be Buried'' (editorial, Aug. 15), most specifically at the next-to-last sentence, which suggests that Carol Bellamy and Harrison Goldin ''rise above narrow neighborhood interests'' in objecting to the proposed incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Were the incinerator
title: Navy Yard Incinerator Endangers Public Health of Brooklyn

title: NEW YORK CITES FOOD OUTLETS

body: AT first glance, the signs of the revitalization that has taken place over the past decade in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn seem no different than evidences of gentrification elsewhere. The brownstones and rowhouses that were little more than burnt-out shells 10 years ago have been carefully restored. Dumpsters packed with rubble from
title: FORT GREENE INTEGRATES AS IT GENTRIFIES

body: Because of an editing error, a report in the Weekender Guide yesterday on ''The Shooting of Dan McGrew'' located Public School 29 in an incorrect district. It is in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn.
title: CORRECTION

body: Friday FOLK-ROCK FROM ENGLAND Contemporary interpretations of traditional English folk tunes will be on the program when three well-known English folk-rock groups join forces for a triple-bill concert tonight. Steeleye Span, one of Britain's most popular folk-rock groups of the 1970's, mixes acoustic and electric music, drawing on traditional folk
title: WEEKENDER GUIDE

body: Ninth Annual Ukrainian Festival, East Seventh Street, between Second and Third Avenues. Today, from 4 to 11 P.M.; tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 11 P.M.; Sunday, 1 to 10 P.M, rain or shine. Entertainment, arts and crafts, homemade food. Sponsored by St. George's Ukrainian Catholic Church, which will benefit from the proceeds. Information: 674-1615. Ye Olde
title: Fairs and Festivals This Weekend

body: The gymnasium is small, just wide enough for the basketball court that fills it, and the paint is peeling from the walls of the exercise room. But the building in Brooklyn Heights has been home to the Brooklyn Central Branch of the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York for 15 years. In January, the Y.M.C.A.'s landlord, Grace Church, sold the building at 62
title: Y.M.C.A. LOSING LEASE ON BUILDING IN BROOKLYN

body: The battered old green car pulls up outside P.S. 29, an elementary school in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn. Out jumps a tall, handsome man in blue cotton pants and running shoes, all grace and exuberance in the morning. Jacques d'Amboise, the legendary principal dancer with the New York City Ballet who has been reborn as the Pied Piper of
title: D'AMBOISE MAKES P.S. 29 FEEL LIKE DANCING

body: SINGLE-FAMILY homes in New York generally come in two price ranges: expensive and unbelievably expensive. As a result, people who have believable incomes and who prefer running their own house to cooperative or condominium living often become landlords - they buy a building with one or more rental apartments that help pay the bills. But this
title: LIVING WITH TENANTS: AN OWNER'S GUIDE

body: There is perhaps no more telling symbol of the transformation of the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn than the current effort to convert the 63-year-old Sacred Heart and St. Stephen's School on Hicks Street into condominium apartments. In recent years the neighborhood of turn-of-the-century brownstones and tree-lined streets, with its vital shopping
title: POSTINGS; THE FOURTH R, FOR RESIDING

body: THE weather is getting warmer. Trees are in bloom. And New Yorkers are emerging onto the streets for the phenomenon known as the Walking Tour. Tour-takers will explore areas from the Bronx to Brooklyn and Staten Island tomorrow and Sunday on what Mayor Koch has proclaimed as ''New York Walkers Weekend.'' They will eat and sing their way through the
title: WHERE TO WALK NOW THAT SPRING'S AFOOT

body: EVEN a feisty official like Mayor Koch surely must endure uncomfortably the criticisms that come with public office. But the Mayor undoubtedly took pleasure last week in decisions by two of his foremost critics to challenge him in the Democratic mayoral primary. Despite months of negotiations, leaders of the constituencies most dissatisfied with
title: HOW TO RUN FOR MAYOR, PHASE 1
